Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the findings of the Pew study by stating that it shows 14 percent of people who voted were noncitizens, when in fact the study does not mention noncitizens voting or registering to vote.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as there is no study that shows 14 percent of the votes cast in 2008 were cast by noncitizens.
Problematic assumption: The claim makes the problematic assumption that noncitizens have swayed elections by voting illegally, based on conflating different studies.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the 2012 Pew study was about outdated voter rolls, not fraudulent votes.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times by misrepresenting the findings of studies and citing incorrect information.
Exist alternative explanation: There is an alternative explanation provided by credible researchers who have criticized the methodology of the study cited by Spicer, suggesting that noncitizen participation does not determine election outcomes.
